The controversy underscores the deeply divided political landscape in the United States, with Democrats and Republicans offering starkly different interpretations of Waters' comments and their implications.

Biden, Harris Hail Chauvin Conviction as Step Forward, Urge Policing Reform

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris hailed the conviction of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd as a step forward in the fight against systemic racism, but stressed that the battle for justice and policing reform is far from over.

"I want to express my sympathy to the Floyd family for their loss," Biden said in a statement Tuesday. "This verdict is a step forward, an essential step forward, but it is not a final one."

Harris, the first Black woman to hold the second-highest office in the U.S., reflected on Floyd's death as a world-changing event with far-reaching implications. "George Floyd's death shocked the entire world," she said. "It tore at the fabric of every American community and it laid bare the painful reality that millions of Black Americans feel too often: that they aren't treated equally under the law."

The White House press secretary, Jen Psaki, added that the administration would continue to push for the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, a sweeping bill to address police misconduct and systemic racism. "We're going to continue to call on Congress to pass this important legislation," she said.

Judge Peter Cahill presided over the three-week trial in Minneapolis and delivered the verdict Tuesday, finding Chauvin guilty of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter. The jury deliberated for about 10 hours over two days.

Brock Hunter, a criminal defense attorney and past president of the Minnesota Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, noted the significance of the verdict for a nation that has seen numerous high-profile police killings go unpunished. "This is a major victory for the Black Lives Matter movement and for those who have been advocating for police reform for decades," he said.

Senator Tim Scott, the highest-ranking Black Republican in Congress, acknowledged the progress made with Chauvin's conviction but echoed Biden's and Harris' call for more reforms. "Today's verdict in the death of George Floyd is a step forward, but it is not enough," he said in a statement. "We need real police reform and we need it now."

Representative Hank Johnson, a Georgia Democrat, echoed that sentiment. "The trial of Derek Chauvin has ended, but our work to bring true justice to George Floyd and to combat systemic racism in our criminal justice system is far from over," he said.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi also weighed in, saying, "Justice has been served, but it is far from the end of our work."

Biden had earlier expressed hope for "the right verdict" while the jury was sequestered, a comment that drew attention. After the verdict, he said he had spoken with Floyd's family to offer comfort and support.

The aftermath of the verdict remains a challenge for Biden, who aims to address policing racism while maintaining support for law enforcement. "We need the vast majority of police officers in this country who are good, decent, honorable men and women to understand that we're going to defend them," he said. "But we're also going to hold those few bad apples accountable."

Reactions to the verdict were mixed, with some expressing relief and a renewed push for policing reform legislation among lawmakers from both parties. Others criticized the verdict as a mere symbolic victory, arguing that more needs to be done to address systemic racism and police brutality.

Biden and Harris urged Americans to continue the fight for justice and equality, warning that the struggle would not be easy. "This moment calls on all of us to come together, to listen to one another, to understand one another, and to work together to build a future where all of us are treated equally in the eyes of the law," Harris said. "We have a lot of work to do."

Biden added, "We're not going to get it right 100% of the time, but we're going to keep trying."

Cruz emphasized, "Under current law, individuals who are not lawfully present in the United States but who have a valid Social Security number can indeed receive a stimulus check."

Durbin's aide, however, criticized the assumption that all visa overstayers have Social Security numbers eligible for stimulus checks. They highlighted that such conditions applied to previous stimulus packages as well. The American Rescue Plan, however, allows anyone paying taxes in the U.S. as a resident, including non-citizens with Social Security numbers, to be eligible for stimulus payments.

Unauthorized immigrants are defined as foreign-born non-citizens living in the U.S. without legal residence. Visa overstayers retain their Social Security numbers, making them potentially eligible for stimulus checks if they pay taxes. In 2019, there were 676,422 visa overstays, with student visas showing the highest overstay rate, according to the Department of Homeland Security.

A spokeswoman for U.S. Customs and Border Protection confirmed that overstaying a visa technically renders someone illegal. The American Rescue Plan's eligibility criteria for stimulus payments extend to legal permanent residents and those passing the substantial presence test, making them eligible for the stimulus payment. The substantial presence test determines an individual's tax residency status based on the number of days they spend in the U.S. during a calendar year.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding Cruz's amendment and the potential eligibility of illegal immigrants for stimulus checks highlights the intricacies of immigration policies and taxation in the U.S. Cruz's concern was valid, as visa overstayers can retain their Social Security numbers and potentially receive stimulus checks if they pay taxes. Defendants Speak Out: The New Trend of Testifying in High-Profile Trials and Its Implications

CHICAGO (AP) – In the realm of criminal trials, the traditional reluctance of defendants to testify in their own defense has been a long-standing rule. However, this trend is gradually shifting, with an increasing number of high-profile defendants deciding to take the stand and challenge the prosecution.

Chicago-based jury consultant Alan Tuerkheimer explains, "Social media and the 24-hour news cycle play a significant role in this change. Defendants may feel a need to tell their side of the story, especially if they believe public opinion is swaying against them."

Two high-profile cases that illustrate this trend are those of former Minneapolis police officer Kim Potter and Kyle Rittenhouse. Potter, who was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of Daunte Wright during a traffic stop, testified in her own defense during her trial in December 2021. Rittenhouse, who is accused of killing two men and wounding another during unrest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in 2020, also took the stand during his trial in November 2021. Potter was found guilty, while Rittenhouse was acquitted.

Tuerkheimer continues, "Jurors today are more likely to be exposed to the defendant's narrative through media coverage, and they may have formed strong opinions before the trial even begins. Testifying gives defendants a chance to address these expectations directly."

Former federal prosecutor Phil Turner remains skeptical about a significant shift in lawyers' attitudes towards defendants testifying. "The decision to testify is a gamble for any defendant. It opens the door to cross-examination, which can potentially lead to damaging admissions or inconsistencies."

Despite these risks, recent trials have seen defendants taking the stand. Among them are Jussie Smollett, Travis McMichael, and Elizabeth Holmes. Smollett, a former "Empire" actor, testified during his trial on charges that he staged a hate crime against himself in 2019. Observers considered his decision to testify a disaster, as he was found guilty on five of the six counts against him. McMichael, one of the three men charged in the death of Ahmaud Arbery, testified in his own defense during his trial in February 2022. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, testified during her trial on fraud charges in January 2022.

A study published in the Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology in 2014 found that 77% of testifying defendants were convicted compared to 72% who did not testify. However, the number of defendants who choose to testify is still relatively small, and studies on defendant testimony are rare.

Defendants with no or minimal criminal records are more likely to testify, potentially due to less risk of exposing a criminal history. Testifying offers a chance to convey one's state of mind, especially crucial in self-defense claims, but comes with risks of cross-examination. Prosecutors may exploit defendants' testimony, looking for inconsistencies or admissions, while not testifying can also be risky, as jurors may fill in the gaps with their own assumptions.

Turner concludes, "Ultimately, the decision to testify is a strategic one that depends on the specific circumstances of each case. For some defendants, the potential benefits may outweigh the risks. For others, it may be better to let their legal team tell their story."

As the criminal justice system continues to evolve, the trend of defendants testifying in their own trials is likely to remain a topic of interest and debate.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – A former Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, was found guilty of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter on Tuesday in the death of George Floyd, a case that triggered worldwide protests and a reexamination of racism and policing in the United States.

The verdict followed three weeks of testimony and about 10 hours of jury deliberations over two days. Chauvin, who was fired from the police department the day after Floyd's death on May 25, 2020, showed no emotion as the judge read out the guilty verdicts.

Philonise Floyd, George Floyd's younger brother, reacted with tears and relief outside the courtroom. "I've been waiting for this day for a long time," he said. "It's been a long journey. It's been a tough journey. But God is good."

The conviction of Chauvin, who is white, for the killing of Floyd, a Black man, was hailed as a step towards justice and systemic reform by President Joe Biden and other leaders. "This verdict sends an essential message: that those who commit violence and abuse are not above the law, and their actions will not be tolerated," Biden said in a statement.

The case emphasized the rare occurrence of police officers being convicted for on-duty killings. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, between 2005 and 2019, only about 0.4% of police killings resulted in officers being charged with murder or manslaughter.

Floyd's death led to widespread protests, removal of Confederate statues, and reforms in policing practices across the country. The tragic event also sparked a global conversation about systemic racism and police brutality.

Sarah Fitzgerald, a Department of Corrections spokeswoman, confirmed that Chauvin would be taken into custody following the verdict and would be transported to the Ramsey County jail in St. Paul. He faces up to 40 years in prison.

President Biden also called on Congress to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, which would, among other things, ban chokeholds, create a national police registry, and limit qualified immunity for officers.

Two witnesses, Janay Henry and Jamee Haggard, testified about the emotional toll Floyd's death had on them and how they begged Chauvin to stop kneeling on Floyd's neck. "I heard George Floyd cry for his mom. I heard him cry for his dad. I heard him cry for his babies," Henry said during her testimony. "I heard him cry for his life."

Prosecutors relied heavily on bystander video showing Floyd's final moments, urging the jury to "Believe your eyes." Medical experts testified that Floyd died from a lack of oxygen due to Chauvin's kneeling on his neck for over nine minutes.

Chauvin's defense argued his actions were reasonable and Floyd's death was due to health issues and drug use. Chauvin did not testify, and his attorney Eric Nelson did not comment following the verdict.

The Justice Department announced an investigation into Minneapolis policing practices following the verdict. Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who represented the Floyd family, called for similar investigations in other cities.

Floyd's death marked a turning point in the national conversation on racial justice and police brutality. While Tuesday's verdict was a significant step towards accountability, it also highlighted the need for continued progress and reform.

Supreme Court Revisits LGBTQ Rights in 303 Creative v. Elenis: A Preemptive Strike on Marriage Equality?

At the heart of the dispute is Lorie Smith, a website designer in Colorado, who seeks the right to refuse service to LGBTQ customers for same-sex weddings based on First Amendment grounds.

Jennifer Pizer, Acting Chief Legal Officer at Lambda Legal, expressed her concerns over the potential implications of a ruling in favor of 303 Creative. "Allowing a business to discriminate against LGBTQ people under the guise of expressive freedom would open the floodgates to widespread discrimination," she warned.

The parallels to previous cases, such as Masterpiece Cakeshop and Fulton v. City of Philadelphia, are unmistakable. In Masterpiece Cakeshop, a bakery refused to sell a wedding cake to a same-sex couple, leading to a contentious legal battle. In Fulton v. City of Philadelphia, a Catholic foster care agency argued that it should be exempted from placing children with same-sex couples based on religious grounds.

However, 303 Creative is unique in that it is not an actual refusal of service but rather a preemptive request for the right to deny services to same-sex couples. Kristen Waggoner, President of Alliance Defending Freedom, which represents 303 Creative, explained, "Lorie simply wants the freedom to express her beliefs through her creative work, without fear of government punishment."

The Supreme Court has opted to focus on the free speech argument, declining to take up the freedom of religion aspect or to reconsider the Smith v. Employment Division precedent. Waggoner argued, "Creative professionals, like Lorie, deserve the same protections afforded to other artists and speakers."

Dale Carpenter, a law professor at Southern Methodist University, and Eugene Volokh, a First Amendment legal scholar at the University of California, Los Angeles, have filed a friend-of-the-court brief in support of 303 Creative's First Amendment claims for expressive goods and services. Carpenter stated, "Artists and creators should have the freedom to choose which messages they wish to convey through their work."

Volokh added, "A ruling in favor of 303 Creative would not only protect the rights of designers like Lorie but also set a precedent for other creators and businesses."

However, critics, including Pizer, warn that a ruling in favor of 303 Creative could legitimize discrimination against LGBTQ individuals under the guise of free speech. "The Supreme Court must recognize that the First Amendment does not give businesses the right to discriminate against marginalized communities," she emphasized.

The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to let the U.S. solicitor general present arguments on behalf of the Biden administration in this case. The solicitor general's role is to represent the interests of the federal government before the Supreme Court.

The outcome of 303 Creative v. Elenis remains uncertain, with both sides presenting compelling arguments. What is clear, however, is that this case will have far-reaching implications for the LGBTQ community and the broader issue of nondiscrimination in America.

Pizer concluded, "The Supreme Court has an opportunity to uphold the principle of nondiscrimination and send a message that all people, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity, deserve equal respect and dignity under the law."

Waggoner countered, "The Supreme Court also has an opportunity to uphold the First Amendment rights of creative professionals and ensure that they are not forced to express messages that violate their deeply held beliefs."

As the Supreme Court prepares to weigh in on this divisive issue, the eyes of the nation will be on the nine justices, who hold the power to shape the future of LGBTQ rights in America.

IRS Distributes 90M COVID-19 Relief Checks Under Biden's American Rescue Plan: Here's How to Check Your Payment Status

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has distributed over 90 million Economic Impact Payments (EIPs), also known as stimulus checks, to Americans under President Joe Biden's American Rescue Plan. With additional payments on the way, the IRS encourages individuals to use the agency's 'Get My Payment' tool to check the status of their stimulus payment.

The 'Get My Payment' tool updates once daily, and the IRS advises against calling for payment information to avoid long wait times. However, taxpayers can use the tool to determine if their payment has been sent, and if not, when they might expect it.

The third round of EIPs is based on either the 2020 or 2019 tax returns, including for non-filers and those who submitted simplified returns. The IRS uses this information to calculate and distribute payments.

Individuals who previously received stimulus checks via direct deposit but won't this time will receive either a check or a prepaid debit card in the mail. The IRS emphasizes the importance of keeping an eye on mailboxes for these payments.

Social Security and federal beneficiaries will generally receive their payments the same way as regular benefits, either by direct deposit or check. The IRS has stated that no action is required for these individuals to receive their stimulus payments.

The stimulus payment amounts to $1,400 for a single person or $2,800 for a married couple, plus $1,400 for each dependent child. This represents a significant increase from previous stimulus payments.

Payments decrease for those earning above $75,000 ($150,000 for couples), phasing out entirely above $80,000 ($160,000 for couples). This means that higher-income individuals will receive smaller or no payments at all.

Due to COVID relief payments and tax refund delays, the IRS has extended the tax filing deadline to May 17, 2021. This extension gives taxpayers an additional two months to file their returns and pay any taxes owed.

To use the 'Get My Payment' tool, taxpayers must provide their Social Security number, tax ID, date of birth, street address, and ZIP code. This information is necessary for the IRS to verify their identity and determine their payment status.

The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 also includes provisions for advance Child Tax Credit payments, which will be distributed monthly from July to December 2021. Eligible families will receive up to $300 per child under age 6 and $250 per child ages 6-17.

Eligible individuals who don't typically file taxes, such as low-income individuals and those experiencing homelessness, can use the Non-Filers: Enter Payment Info Here tool on the IRS website to register for stimulus payments and Child Tax Credit payments.

The IRS urges taxpayers to be cautious of scams related to stimulus payments and Child Tax Credit payments. Scammers may use fake emails, texts, or phone calls to trick individuals into providing sensitive information.

The IRS emphasizes that it will never contact individuals by email, text, or social media to request personal or financial information. Taxpayers should only provide such information through official IRS channels, such as the 'Get My Payment' tool or the IRS website.

If taxpayers encounter issues with the 'Get My Payment' tool or have other questions about their stimulus payment or tax refund, they can contact the IRS at 1-800-829-1040. The IRS encourages taxpayers to have their taxpayer identification number, Social Security number, and mailing address on hand when calling.

As the IRS continues to distribute stimulus payments and process tax refunds, it's important for taxpayers to stay informed and be patient. FDA Authorizes Emergency Use of AstraZeneca's Evusheld for Pre-Exposure Prevention of COVID-19 in Certain Individuals

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today announced the issuance of an emergency use authorization (EUA) for AstraZeneca's Evusheld (tixagevimab co-packaged with cilgavimab) for pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) of COVID-19 in adults and pediatric individuals 12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms (~88 pounds). This authorization covers individuals not currently infected with SARS-CoV-2, not recently exposed to it, and either immunocompromised or having a history of severe adverse reactions to COVID-19 vaccines.

Patrizia Cavazzoni, M.D., Acting FDA Commissioner and Director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, emphasized the importance of COVID-19 vaccines for the majority of the population. "Vaccines continue to be the best way to prevent COVID-19," she stated. "However, we recognize that vaccines are not an option for some individuals, and today's action provides an additional tool to help prevent infection in these individuals."

Evusheld consists of a combination of two long-acting monoclonal antibodies, tixagevimab and cilgavimab, which are designed to block the virus by targeting the spike protein. The treatment is administered via two consecutive intramuscular injections and is intended for a six-month efficacy period. It is not a substitute for COVID-19 vaccines and should only be used in individuals who do not have access to or cannot receive COVID-19 vaccines and meet the specified criteria.

Dr. Cavazzoni continued, "Today's authorization provides an important alternative for individuals who cannot receive a COVID-19 vaccine due to a medical condition or a history of severe adverse reactions and are at high risk for infection. We will continue to evaluate data as it becomes available to support the use of COVID-19 therapeutics."

The primary data for the EUA comes from the PROVENT clinical trial, which showed a 77% reduced risk of developing COVID-19 for Evusheld recipients over those receiving a placebo. The most common side effects of Evusheld include hypersensitivity reactions, bleeding at the injection site, headache, fatigue, cough, and, in rare cases, serious cardiac adverse events.

Dr. Cavazzoni emphasized the importance of continuing to monitor the safety and efficacy of COVID-19 therapeutics. "The FDA remains committed to ensuring that Americans have access to safe and effective COVID-19 treatments, vaccines, and prevention options, and we will continue to work closely with sponsors to expedite the development and review of these critical products," she said.

The FDA encourages healthcare professionals and patients to report any adverse events related to Evusheld or any other COVID-19 product to the FDA's MedWatch Safety Information and Adverse Event Reporting Program. The FDA reiterates that vaccination remains recommended for those eligible, emphasizing the authorization of various COVID-19 vaccines.

Facebook's Six-Hour Global Outage: A Single Point of Failure Exposed

In an unprecedented turn of events, Facebook and its associated platforms, including Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger, experienced a global outage that lasted close to six hours on Monday, October 4, 2021. The outage, which affected millions of users worldwide, left many wondering about the resilience of the social media giant's infrastructure.

According to early reports, the outage was caused by a configuration change to the backbone routers that coordinate network traffic between Facebook's data centers. Cloudflare, a leading cloud security and DNS provider, later provided a detailed explanation of the incident.

Cloudflare's analysis revealed that the outage involved DNS (Domain Name System) and BGP (Border Gateway Protocol), two crucial components for internet connectivity. DNS translates domain names into IP addresses, while BGP helps direct traffic between different networks.

The disruption brought all Facebook services to a standstill, affecting both public-facing platforms and internal systems. This resulted in staff being locked out of offices and unable to use the internal communications platform, causing further complications in resolving the issue.

Since the internal systems were down, it took a considerable amount of time for Facebook's technical team to diagnose and resolve the problem. The drawn-out process was due, in part, to the inability to access crucial data and tools required for effective troubleshooting.

Facebook eventually indicated that the fix was slow due to the need to bring systems back to full capacity carefully. A technical team had to manually reset servers in California where the problem originated to ensure a stable recovery.

Such outages, while uncommon, highlight the issues with a single point of failure for online services. The incident underscores the importance of distributed systems, redundancy, and resilience to prevent prolonged service disruptions.

The outage occurred during a particularly challenging time for Facebook. Plans for an Instagram for kids had recently been paused due to concerns over privacy and child safety, while whistleblower allegations regarding the company's handling of user data continued to mount.

The timing of the outage could not have come at a worse moment for Facebook. The company's share price dropped 4.9% as a result of the incident, reducing CEO Mark Zuckerberg's personal wealth by an estimated $6 billion.

The impact of the outage was far-reaching, affecting both individual users and businesses that rely on Facebook's platforms for marketing and communication. Many businesses reported lost revenue due to the extended downtime.

The outage also raised questions about Facebook's commitment to transparency and accountability. Some critics suggested that the lack of clear communication during the incident underscored the need for greater oversight and regulation of tech companies.

Facebook's initial response to the outage was met with frustration from users who were unable to access their accounts or communicate with friends and family. Many took to alternative platforms, such as Twitter, to voice their concerns and share their experiences.

As the outage wore on, Facebook's technical team worked tirelessly to identify and resolve the root cause of the issue. They provided regular updates on their progress and assured users that they were doing everything in their power to restore services as soon as possible.

The outage eventually came to an end, with Facebook announcing that services had been fully restored. The company expressed its apologies for the inconvenience caused and pledged to learn from the incident to prevent similar occurrences in the future.

In the aftermath of the outage, experts weighed in on the implications for Facebook and the tech industry as a whole. Some suggested that the incident could lead to increased scrutiny of tech companies and their infrastructure, while others saw it as an opportunity for Facebook to demonstrate its commitment to resilience and reliability.

As the dust settles on the six-hour Facebook outage, one thing is clear: the incident serves as a reminder of the importance of robust, distributed systems and the need for continuous improvement in the face of ever-evolving technological challenges.

SEAL Team 6 Founding Commander Richard "Dick" Marcinko, Known as "Rogue Warrior," Dies at 81

In a shocking turn of events, the military community and the world of special operations lost a legendary figure on Christmas night. Richard "Dick" Marcinko, the founding commander of SEAL Team 6, passed away at the age of 81. The news was announced by his son, Matthew Marcinko, on Twitter.

Matthew Marcinko wrote, "It is with a heavy heart that I announce the passing of my father, Richard 'Dick' Marcinko, at the age of 81. He died peacefully in his sleep from what appears to be a heart attack."

Marcinko's career in the Navy SEALs began in 1967 when he was deployed to Vietnam as a member of SEAL Team Two. He led a highly successful operation in the Mekong Delta, showcasing his innovative leadership and tactical skills.

During the Iran hostage crisis in 1979, Marcinko was a part of the Terrorist Action Team (TAT), which was tasked with freeing American hostages in Tehran. The failure of Operation Eagle Claw led Marcinko to form the dedicated counter-terrorist unit, SEAL Team 6.

Retired Navy SEAL Adm. Eric Olson described Marcinko as "imaginative, bold, and a warrior at heart." Olson, who served as the head of U.S. Special Operations Command from 2009 to 2011, added, "His contributions to the Navy SEALs and his innovative leadership of SEAL Team 6 left a lasting legacy."

After retiring in 1989, Marcinko became a best-selling author with books such as Rogue Warrior, which chronicled the adventures of a fictional character named Marcinko. The books' success solidified his status as a pop culture icon and a household name.

Marcinko's impact on the military world extended beyond his time with SEAL Team 6. He was a key figure in the development of the Navy's Maritime Special Purpose Force (MSPF), a precursor to today's Naval Special Warfare Development Group (NSWDG), also known as DEVGRU or SEAL Team 6.

"My father was a pioneer in the special operations community," Matthew Marcinko told PEOPLE in a statement. "He was a visionary, a trailblazer, and a true American hero. His legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched and inspired."

DarkSide Ransomware Group's "Double Extortion" Tactics: Stealing Data Before Encrypting and Threatening Public Disclosure

The DarkSide ransomware group, known for its "double extortion" tactics, operated as a "ransomware-as-a-service" (RaaS) model, recruiting affiliates to launch attacks on unsuspecting organizations since its emergence in August 2020. According to Christopher Ballod, Associate Managing Director for Cyber Risk at Kroll, "DarkSide represents a significant threat due to their advanced techniques and financial acumen."

DarkSide's "double extortion" strategy involves stealing sensitive data before encrypting files, giving the group leverage to demand larger ransoms or sell the stolen information to third parties. Phil Wittmann, an attorney at Stone Pigman Walther Wittmann, explained, "The theft of data before encryption increases the pressure on organizations to pay the ransom to prevent the public exposure of their confidential information."

DarkSide carefully selected its targets based on financial analysis and information gleaned from corporate emails. Michael Walshe Jr., Chair of the Management Committee at Stone Pigman Walther Wittmann, stated, "DarkSide's targeted approach to selecting victims demonstrates a high level of sophistication and planning."

To infiltrate target networks, DarkSide employed advanced techniques like "zero-day exploits," which exploit vulnerabilities in software for which no patch is yet available. Ballod noted, "Zero-day exploits give attackers a significant advantage, as they can bypass security measures that rely on known vulnerabilities."

Once inside a target's network, DarkSide moved swiftly to encrypt files and exfiltrate data. They also investigated victims' cyber insurance policies to tailor ransom demands effectively. Wittmann commented, "DarkSide's understanding of cyber insurance policies is a testament to their research capabilities and knowledge of the cyber threat landscape."

DarkSide's quick attack window and demands on the high end, typically $5 million or more, put pressure on organizations to respond rapidly. Ballod cautioned, "The window of opportunity for organizations to prevent a ransomware attack is shrinking, making it essential for them to invest in robust cybersecurity measures and incident response plans."

DarkSide threatened to share stolen information with short-sellers if publicly traded companies refused to pay the ransom. Wittmann warned, "The potential for public disclosure of sensitive information can lead to significant reputational damage and financial losses for organizations."

After DarkSide's shutdown by law enforcement, affiliates complained on a forum that they had not been paid their share of the ransoms. Walshe Jr. commented, "The lack of transparency in ransomware-as-a-service operations can lead to mistrust among affiliates and potential legal repercussions."

Seven of Tantleff's clients paid ransoms ranging from $1.25 million to $6 million after negotiations from higher initial demands. Wittmann emphasized, "Paying the ransom is not an ideal solution, but it may be the most effective way to mitigate the damage caused by a ransomware attack and prevent the public disclosure of sensitive information."

Capitol Riot Defendants' Unwavering Loyalty to Trump: A Legal Strategy or Empty Excuse?

As the legal proceedings against nearly 200 individuals charged in connection to the Capitol riot continue, a common thread has emerged: many defendants claim they were following former President Donald Trump's directives when they stormed the Capitol on January 6, 2021.

"My client, Garret Miller, was under the belief that he was acting in accordance with the instructions of the President of the United States," said Clint Broden, Miller's attorney.

Enrique Latoison, attorney for Robert Sanford, another defendant, echoed similar sentiments, "My client believes that he was acting under the color of law, responding to what he believed to be a call to action from the former President."

Legal experts, however, believe that while Trump's influence may not exonerate the accused, it could potentially lead to reduced sentences or plea deals.

Michael Stokes Paulsen, a law professor at the University of St. Thomas, said, "There's a chance that the extent of Trump's influence could be considered as a mitigating factor. But it's unlikely to completely absolve defendants."

Defendants have cited Trump's rhetoric, especially his speech on January 6 urging supporters to "fight like hell," as a call to action. Ziv Cohen, a clinical psychiatrist, explained, "There's a phenomenon known as the 'charismatic leader' effect. Trump's words had a profound impact on his followers."

However, Trump's defense attorneys deny that he incited the riot, placing the blame squarely on the rioters themselves. Daniel Richman, a law professor at Columbia University, noted, "There's a significant difference between inspiring passion and inciting violence. The former is protected by the First Amendment, the latter is not."

Statements by the accused that they were acting on Trump's instructions may also be used in the impeachment trial against him. The concept of "public authority defense" might be argued, suggesting rioters believed they were acting on government orders.

"The public authority defense is a long-standing principle in criminal law. It's based on the idea that people may reasonably believe they're following lawful orders," Paulsen explained.

Experts, however, are skeptical that shifting blame to Trump will significantly impact the legal outcomes for the accused individuals. Latoison acknowledged, "It's a strategy, but it won't be an easy sell."

Some rioters explicitly stated that their actions were in response to Trump's call, including storming the Capitol if he requested. One defendant's statement read, "I would do anything for President Trump. If he asked me to storm the Capitol, I would have."

The influence of Trump and other officials may be considered as a mitigating factor, though unlikely to completely absolve defendants. As Paulsen put it, "The law recognizes that people are influenced by the powerful figures in their lives. But ultimately, individuals are responsible for their own actions."

As the legal proceedings unfold, it remains to be seen how much weight the courts will give to the defendants' claims of following Trump's instructions. Regardless, the events of January 6, 2021, continue to reverberate, both in the courtroom and in the broader national discourse.

Suez Canal's Ever Given Ships Out 106 Days After Blockage, Compensation Settlement Reached

ISMAILIA, Egypt, July 7 (Reuters) – The Ever Given container ship, which blocked the Suez Canal for 106 days and disrupted global trade, resumed its journey on Wednesday, leaving Egyptian waters after a compensation settlement was reached between the ship's representatives and the Suez Canal Authority (SCA).

Tarek Alzeki, the captain of a tugboat that helped refloat the Ever Given, watched as the ship, loaded with about 18,300 containers, sailed north across the Great Bitter Lake. "It's a relief to finally see it go," Alzeki told Reuters, "but it's been a long wait for all of us."

The Ever Given had been held under court order while the SCA sought compensation from its owner, Shoei Kisen, and insurers. An undisclosed settlement was reached between the parties, with some compensation to be paid this month, according to Khalid Abubakr, a lawyer for the SCA.

The Ever Given had been due for a hull inspection before sailing to its next port, but R P Veetil, General Secretary of the Sailors Union of India, said that was no longer necessary. "The ship is in a seaworthy condition," Veetil said. "The inspection can be done at the next port of call."

The SCA aims to keep the terms of the agreement confidential, but Osama Rabie, SCA Chairman, confirmed that the ship had been released. "The Ever Given is now free to leave the Suez Canal," Rabie said. "We are pleased that this matter has been resolved amicably."

About 15% of world shipping traffic transits the Suez Canal, highlighting its importance to global trade. The incident has led to a push to widen and deepen the southernmost section of the canal and extend a second lane.

Yukito Higaki, a spokesman for Imabari shipbuilding, a subsidiary of Shoei Kisen, said the company would cooperate with the SCA on the expansion project. "We understand the importance of the Suez Canal to global trade," Higaki said. "We are committed to working with the SCA to ensure the safe and efficient passage of ships through the canal."

Guy Platten, Secretary General of the International Chamber of Shipping, welcomed the resolution of the dispute. "The Ever Given incident highlighted the importance of the Suez Canal to global trade," Platten said. "We are pleased that the matter has been resolved and that the canal remains open for business."

Rules for ships transiting the canal in difficult weather conditions will not change, Rabie said. "The safety of ships and crews is our top priority," Rabie said. "We will continue to enforce the rules strictly to ensure the safe and efficient passage of ships through the Suez Canal."

The Ever Given grounded in the Suez Canal on March 23, causing a traffic jam of more than 400 ships. The incident disrupted global supply chains and led to increased shipping costs.

The SCA estimated the cost of the blockage at $95 million per day. The Ever Given's owners and insurers have estimated the cost of the incident at around $300 million.

The Ever Given was refloated on March 29 with the help of a flotilla of tugboats and dredgers. The ship was taken to the Great Bitter Lake for inspections and repairs.

The SCA had initially demanded $1 billion in compensation from Shoei Kisen, but the amount was later reduced to around $550 million. The settlement amount was not disclosed.

The Ever Given is due to call at the Port of Rotterdam in the Netherlands, the world's largest container port, before continuing on to its final destination in Felixstowe, UK.

The Suez Canal is a vital artery for global trade, linking Europe and Asia. The canal is 193.3 kilometers (120 miles) long and 6.4 meters (21 feet) deep. It can accommodate ships with a maximum draft of 7 meters (23 feet).
